title: 107_s2078
content: Exemption for certain state and local political committees from notification, reporting, and annual return requirements under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Exemption for state and local political organizations from certain IRS requirements. Amend the Internal Revenue Code to include exempt State or local political organizations. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of a political organization that focuses on influencing the selection of individuals for public office. It emphasizes the organization's reporting requirements to the state. The curr_chunk explains that an organization will not be considered to have failed to meet reporting requirements solely due to certain specified reasons. The organization will not be considered to have failed reporting requirements if State law requires reporting of contributions over $300 greater than federal law or does not require identifying contributors' employers or occupations. The organization must report the employer, occupation, and purpose of any expenditures made. Minor errors in complying with State law are allowed if corrected promptly. The term 'exempt State or local political organization' excludes organizations where a candidate for or holder of a Federal public office controls the organization, solicits contributions, or directs disbursements. Annual income tax returns are required only for political organization taxable income. The amendment to section 6033 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 requires political organizations with gross receipts of $25,000 or more to file information returns. Exempt State or local political organizations are excluded if controlled by a Federal public office candidate or holder. The amendment requires political organizations with gross receipts of $25,000 or more to file information returns. Exempt State or local political organizations can substitute $100,000 for $25,000. The Secretary will review the annual return required under section 6033(g) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for possible modification. The amendments made by this section will take effect as if included in the amendments made by Public Law 106-230. SEC. 3. NOTIFICATION OF INTERACTION OF REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Federal Election Commission, shall publicize the effect of the amendments made by this Act and the interaction of requirements to file a notification or report under section 527 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and reports under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Information provided shall be included in any appropriate form, instruction, notice, or other guidance issued to the public by the Secretary of the Treasury or the Federal Election Commission regarding reporting requirements of political organizations. SEC. 4. WAIVER OF PENALTIES. SEC. 4. WAIVER OF PENALTIES. The Secretary may waive tax penalties for failure to give notice or file a report if failure was due to reasonable cause. Effective after June 30, 2000. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include provisions regarding unsegregated funds not avoiding tax, procedures for assessment and collection of penalties, and the elimination of duplicate written filings requirement. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow electronic filing of notices and reports, eliminating the requirement for duplicate written filings. Additionally, the application of the fraud penalty is expanded to include specific sections related to filing under subsections (i) and (j) of section 527. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include changes in the contents of reports and notices for section 527 organizations. This includes adding details such as date and purpose to reports, specifying intentions to claim exemptions in notices, and adjusting the timing of notices. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include changes in the timing of notices for section 527 organizations. Material changes must be reported within 30 days, and the effective dates for these amendments vary depending on the type of failure or filing. Material changes must be reported within 30 days, and the effective dates for these amendments vary depending on the type of failure or filing. The changes shall apply to material changes on or after the date of the enactment of this Act.
